sentence: The stock market is cautiously higher today, supported by gains in the retail sector and safe-haven demand for U.S. investments amid new concern for emerging markets.

Although traders are still skittish ahead of tomorrow's release of FOMC minutes, better-than-expected earnings this morning from Best Buy ( BBY ) and Home Depot ( HD ) have renewed market confidence in consumer spending and an improving housing sector.

European markets continued to be pressured by the expectation that the Federal Open Markets Committee minutes will signal an imminent tapering of the Fed's $85-billion bond-buying program, with a resulting rise in international bond yield in response.
Although the downside is tempered by the flight out of emerging markets, all three major European indices finished in the red.
Crude oil was down $0.79 to $106.31 per barrel.
Natural gas was up $0.03 to $3.64 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $8.90 to $1,374.70 an ounce, while silver was up $0.03 to $23.24 an ounce.
Copper was unchanged at $3.34 per pound.

Among energy ETFs , the United States Oil Fund was down 0.68% to $37.91 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was up 1.04% to $18.42 Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was up 2.85% to 30.13 while SPDR Gold Shares were up 0.49% to $132.65.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 0.10% to $22.32.

Here's where the U.S. markets stand at mid-day:

(+) BBY (+9.4%) The consumer electronics retailer surges to a 30-month high on much better than expected Q2 earnings

(+) XOMA (+14.1%) Prices offering of 7.6 million shares at $3.62 each.
(-) GASS (-10.0%) Q2 EPS of $0.16 trails estimates by $0.11 per share and is down from a $0.31 profit in the year-ago quarter.
(-) BKS (-15.0%) Reports wider-than-expected Q1 net loss; board chairman Leonard Riggio also suspends bid to buy the company's retail business.
